title: How to Dye Synthetic Fabric Black

steps.title: Weigh your fabric to see how much dye you need.
steps.content: Weigh your fabric to see how much dye you need. Fold up your fabric and place it on a kitchen scale. Weight it in pounds to see how much dye you’ll need to add to cover the entirety of your fabric. [1] X Research source Usually, you need to use 1 bottle of dye for every 2 pounds (0.91 kg) of fabric. Check on the back of the bottle of your fabric for the specific amount of dye you need to use.

steps.title: Purchase a black dye made specifically for synthetic fabric.
steps.content: Purchase a black dye made specifically for synthetic fabric. Synthetic fabrics, like polyester, nylon, acrylic, and acetate take dye differently than natural fibers. Make sure the dye you are purchasing says that it is specifically for synthetic fabrics so you know that it will work. [2] X Research source You can find synthetic fabric dye at most craft supply stores. Rit Dye, Jacquard Dye, and Dylon Dye make synthetic dyes in a liquid or powder form.

steps.title: Wash the fabric like you normally would.
steps.content: Wash the fabric like you normally would. Check the care instructions on the label of your fabric and wash it with water and detergent. Rinse it out well so there isn’t any detergent left before you start dyeing. [3] X Research source Pre-washing the fabric will remove any coatings that could be on the outside of the fabric from manufacturing.

steps.title: Cover your work surface and put on gloves.
steps.content: Cover your work surface and put on gloves. Fabric dye can and will stain your skin and your work surface. Use a plastic tarp or paper bags to cover the area you’ll be working in, and use rubber gloves to protect your hands. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Fill a stainless steel pot with water.
steps.content: Fill a stainless steel pot with water. You can estimate how much water you need by putting your fabric into the pot and seeing how much room it takes up. Use enough water for your fabric to move around freely in the pot. [5] X Research source Usually this is about 3 pounds (1.4 kg) of water for every 1 pound (0.45 kg) of fabric. Use a large stainless-steel pot for even dyeing, which you can find affordably at thrift stores. Stainless steel won’t stain when it comes into contact with the dye.

steps.title: Add 1 teaspoon (4.9 mL) of dish soap to the water.
steps.content: Add 1 teaspoon (4.9 mL) of dish soap to the water. Try to use a mild dish soap without any fragrances or dyes. The dish soap helps to reduce the surface tension of the water, which will allow the dye to penetrate your fabric. [6] X Research source Some fabric dyes recommend that you add salt or vinegar to the mixture, but you don’t have to do that with synthetic dyes.

steps.title: Bring the water to just below a boil on the stove.
steps.content: Bring the water to just below a boil on the stove. Turn your stovetop to medium-high heat and let it sit. Watch for small bubbles that begin to rise to the surface of the water, then turn your heat down so that it stays at that level. [7] X Research source If your water does start to boil, just turn your heat down slightly and wait for the water to cool down. Non-synthetic dye doesn’t have to be mixed with hot water, but synthetic dye does.

steps.title: Pour your dye into the water and stir it around.
steps.content: Pour your dye into the water and stir it around. Read the instructions on your package of dye to figure out how much you need for your fabric. Use a metal spoon to stir the dye well so that it is evenly mixed into the water. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Wet your fabric, then add it to the pot.
steps.content: Wet your fabric, then add it to the pot. Quickly run your fabric under the sink and wring out the excess water. Lower it down gently into the pot of dye, making sure you don’t splash yourself. [9] X Research source You can use tongs to put your fabric into the water if it’s easier. Avoid overloading the pot; the fabric needs space to move freely in the water.

steps.title: Stir your fabric for 10 to 30 minutes.
steps.content: Stir your fabric for 10 to 30 minutes. If you want your fabric lighter, take it out earlier. If you want it a darker color, keep it in for the full 30 minutes. Keep stirring your fabric constantly so that it moves around the pot the entire time it’s in the dye. [10] X Research source Nylon reacts super quickly to dye, while polyester can take a long time to pick up the dye.

steps.title: Rinse the fabric in warm water until the water runs clear.
steps.content: Rinse the fabric in warm water until the water runs clear. Use tongs to take your fabric out of the water, and remember that it will be super hot. Rinse it with warm water in the sink until you can’t see any dye running out, or for about 5 minutes. [11] X Research source Make sure you are wearing your gloves, or the dye will stain your hands.

steps.title: Wash the fabric in warm water with detergent.
steps.content: Wash the fabric in warm water with detergent. You can hand wash your fabric or put it into the washing machine on its own. Use warm water and a few drops of detergent to wash and rinse your dye. [12] X Research source The dye will probably run the first time you wash your fabric, so it’s important to wash it on its own.

steps.title: Hang the fabric to dry.
steps.content: Hang the fabric to dry. Fold your fabric over a clothes rack or clothesline and wait until it’s fully dry. Now you can use your fabric in sewing clothes, doing embroidery, or other crafts! [13] X Research source
